subject: RE: [junit] How JUnit is better than other Java testing framework?
msgSnippet: I don t like QA 101 homework assignments, and most of the people here don t either.  Could you please show some evidence of a little research? I assume someone
messageBody:
I don't like QA 101 homework assignments, and most of the people here
don't either. Could you please show some evidence of a little research?
I assume someone is paying you a salary to discover this for yourself.
You obviously haven't put the slightest effort into investigating these
tools.

Scott Stirling
Framingham, MA

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Shay Hassidim [mailto:shay@...]
>
> Thank you George for this reply.
> I really like JUnit and would like to use it as part our
> company testing procedures , but I need to justify the usage
> of it and to explain what are its advantages.
>
> For now , the advantages I can find at this framework are:
> - Allowing testing at the method level granularity.
> - Running the testing methods automatically. No need to deal
> with maintain caller methods.
>
> Could you add more?
>
> Thanks,
> Shay
>
>
> -----Original Message-----

> Off the top of my head, most of those don't seem to do the
> same things as junit. Which is better, a bicycle or a
> banana? Why don't you sort your list according to what they
> actually do? Code coverage testing, for example, is
> orthoganal to unit and regression testing.
>
> I don't know all of those tools, but I know Jtest uses Junit.
> And if you're looking at static analysis tools, you should
> also take a look at RevJava.
>
> - George
